content.title: Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury
content.definition: Paradoxical tissue damage occurring when blood flow is restored to previously ischemic tissue, caused by inflammatory cascades, oxidative stress, and release of toxic metabolites. A major determinant of outcome in acute limb ischemia, manifesting as local (compartment syndrome) and systemic (SIRS, MODS) complications.

key_concepts.description: Ischemia depletes ATP → calcium influx → cell damage. Reperfusion delivers oxygen → reactive oxygen species formation → endothelial activation → neutrophil recruitment → inflammatory cascade → further tissue damage
Potassium (hyperkalemia), myoglobin (myoglobinuria, renal failure), lactate (acidosis), and inflammatory cytokines wash into systemic circulation upon revascularization
Sudden release of potassium from ischemic muscle can cause fatal cardiac arrhythmias; particularly dangerous with bilateral revascularization or prolonged ischemia
Myoglobin from damaged muscle precipitates in renal tubules causing acute tubular necrosis; urine appears brown/red; treat with aggressive IV fluids, alkalinization, mannitol
Local manifestation of reperfusion injury; post-revascularization swelling in closed fascial compartments increases pressure → compresses arterioles → secondary ischemia. Requires fasciotomy
Prophylactic if ischemia >4-6 hours or high clinical suspicion; therapeutic if compartment pressure >30 mmHg or clinical signs (pain on passive stretch, tense compartments)
Severe reperfusion injury causes SIRS → multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS) → ARDS, acute kidney injury, DIC. May be fatal even if limb is viable
In severe cases with irreversible muscle damage and impending lethal reperfusion syndrome, primary amputation may be considered to prevent systemic toxicity
Minimize ischemia time; staged reperfusion (gradual clamp release); hypothermia; mannitol; free radical scavengers (largely experimental); vigilant monitoring
Serial potassium levels; lactate; urine output and myoglobin; renal function; limb compartments; cardiac monitoring for arrhythmias

learning_objectives: Understand the pathophysiology of ischemia-reperfusion injury
Recognize systemic manifestations (hyperkalemia, acidosis, renal failure)
Know when to perform prophylactic fasciotomy
Appreciate that the systemic response can be more dangerous than limb ischemia
clinical_pearls: Potassium surge upon reperfusion can cause cardiac arrest - be prepared
Ischemia >4-6 hours = high risk for compartment syndrome = low threshold for fasciotomy
Dark urine = myoglobinuria = aggressive hydration + consider mannitol + alkalinization
Sometimes amputation saves life by preventing lethal reperfusion
Monitor K+, lactate, urine output, limb compartments closely post-revasc
MODS from reperfusion injury has high mortality
common_mistakes: Not anticipating hyperkalemia (have calcium gluconate ready)
Delayed fasciotomy leading to secondary ischemia
Revascularizing irreversible limb and causing fatal reperfusion syndrome
